snippet: In New York’s “outer boroughs,” accusations of neglect seemed colored by a growing belief that the recovery from Hurricane Sandy has split along predictable class lines.
abstract: Rockaways, a narrow peninsula of working-class communities in Queens, have become one of the epicenters for the simmering sense of abandonment felt in still-darkened areas of New York City after Hurricane Sandy; around the city, particularly in places already sensitive to the afterthought status conveyed in the Manhattan-centric characterization of them as 'outer boroughs,' accusations of neglect seem colored by a growing belief that the recovery has cleaved along predictable class lines.
lead_paragraph: In New York’s “outer boroughs,” accusations of neglect seemed colored by a growing belief that the recovery from Hurricane Sandy has split along predictable class lines.

headline.seo: In Sight of Manhattan Skyline, a Population Lives Forlorn and in the Dark
headline.main: In Sight of Manhattan Skyline, Living Forlorn and in the Dark
headline.print_headline: In Sight of Manhattan Skyline, Living Forlorn and in the Dark
